description.value: Wooden shabti of Huy: the slender mummiform body has been exquisitely modelled and the details of the elaborately curled wig and the agricultural tools which Huy holds have been rendered in masterly fashion. The smoothed surface of the wood has been left unpainted for the most part, undoubtedly to emphasize the pattern of the grain. Against this ground the wig, facial features and details of the collar have been painted in contrasting black and white, and the incised hieroglyphs of the inscriptions were originally filled with a blue pigment. The long text in nine horizontal lines on the front of the body contains the shabti-spell from Chapter 6 of the 'Book of the Dead', to ensure that the figure performed its tasks properly. The owner's name and title occur at the beginning, and these are repeated on the back of the shabti in a single vertical line. Huy's figure is well-equipped with a hoe and mattock and with a grain basket suspended from two cords on his back—all skillfully carved in shallow relief.

description.value: Painted sycomore fig wood shabti of a Scribe of God's Offerings of All the Gods named Bakenkhons, with a black lappet wig, a brown face, the front of the body down to the crossed arms is yellow, the collar is blue, the brown hands are depicted holding two red hoes, the legs are inscribed with a central column of black hieroglyphs on yellow ground, the edges of the legs and the back are painted white overlain with a representation of a red seed-basket and a red yoke with two nu-pots on the back of either arm.

description.value: Wooden shabti of Djymyr covered in a layer of painted plaster with a short blue and black lappet-wig with yellow braids, a brown face with black features, representations of black ear-studs, a yellow and black collar with a decorative blue tasselled border, brown crossed hands in relief with one holding a single yellow hoe, the front of the legs are inscribed with seven rows of black incised hieroglyphs separated by red lines, the body is white(now discoloured), the back is decorated with a red and black representation of a seed-basket hanging from one shoulder, the whole figure is thickly varnished.

description.value: Painted limestone shabti of a woman: the figure is mummiform and holds the standard shabti equipment of hoe, mattock, and seed baskets; but the luxuriant wig is the hairstyle of a living woman. The paint on the upper part of this statuette is well preserved, enabling one to see that alternate lines of her eight rows of shabti text were colored yellow, to simulate gold, and that a row of dots was painted just under the front of her wig to indicate the fringe of her natural hair. The white limestone of the face was left unpainted, except for red on the lips and black to mark the line dividing the lips, as well as the eyes and eyebrows.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Painted pottery shabti of Bakhapy(?) with blackening blue striated lappet wig with red-striped yellow terminals, blue and yellow banded collar, white body with red water-pots and basket on back, and red central square beneath wrists; red painted face with white eyes, black pupils and cosmetic lines; arms crossed in relief with hands red holding black (over red ?) painted hoes (not in relief); lower front and sides with four horizontal lines of black hieroglyphs against yellow background with red dividing lines, with narrower band without text below last; red central band at feet. Text gives part of chapter 6 of the Book of the Dead.

description.value: Painted sycomore fig wood shabti of Khonsemheb with a blue flat-topped lappet wig, a brown face, the front of the body down to the crossed arms is painted yellow overlain with a representation of a blue and red collar and brown hands holding two red hoes, the front of the legs is inscribed with a central column of black painted hieroglyphs on a yellow ground flanked by blue lines, the rest of the leg-area is painted white at the front with a red line running down either edge, the back has a yellow seed-basket and a yoke with two nu-pots, the feet are differentiated by a groove.
